citation.article-title: Streptococcus parasanguis sp. nov., an atypical viridans Streptococcus from human clinical specimens.

p.s: Description of Streptococcus parasanguis sp. nov.
Streptococcus parasanguis (Gr. prep. para resembling: L. n. sanguis blood; parasanguis resembling S. sanguis)
Cells are coccoid (ca. 0.8 to 1.0 μm diam.) and occur in chains.
Produce an a-reaction on blood agar.
Most strains grow at 45 °C and in the presence of 40% bile but not in the presence of 4% NaCl.
Acid is produced from fructose, galactose, glucose, lactose, maltose, sucrose, but not from adonitol, arabinose, glycogen, inulin, mannitol, melezitose or xylose.
Virtually all strains fermet raffinose and salicin but not amygdalin, glycerol, sorbitol or starch.
Variable results are obtained with cellobiose, melibiose and trehalose.
Starch is hydrolysed but hippurate is not.
Cells produce hydrogen peroxide and leucine amylamidase but not acetoin, urease, pyrrolidonylarylamidase, or β-glucuronidasc.
The majority of strains produce alkaline phosphatase.
Some strains produce agalactosidase and β-galactosidase and hydrolyse aesculin (APl).
Cells bind salivary a-amylase, The guanine plus cytosine content of DNA is from 40.6-42.7 mol%.
Source: human clinical specimens (throat, blood and urine).
